messageBody:
2006/9/11, Lasse Koskela <lasse.koskela@...>:
>
> Hi Bob,
>
> I'm surprised that nobody has suggested this before but perhaps I'm
> just not thinking straight (a 4+ hour flight behind me and another one
> to go in 5 hours...)
>
> How about using AOP bytecode weaving for replacing the calls to
> System.exit() with your fake implementation?
>
> Perhaps something like this:
>
> public aspect SystemExitTestingAspect {
>
> pointcut systemExit(int reason) :
> call(java.lang.System.exit(int)) && args(reason);
>
> void around(int reason) : systemExit(reason) {
> fake.java.lang.System.exit(reason);
> }
> }
>
> Sounds like a very neat solution, however I am not sure how you would do
this with the JDK classes.
If you have to weave the aspect in the class file that might be a bit much
trouble with the JDK libraries.
How good is the support these days for weaving at runtime when classes are
loaded etc? And can you
do it for a class like System? If that works, it should be a workable
solution. If you do get it working,
how do you finally exit your test framework? This sounds complicated :).

I'm not an expert on AOP so maybe someone else can shed some light on what
is the state of the art at the
AOP tool front?
